awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Risky Homes, Domestic Accidents, and Safety Work
awd_abstract_narration:
Accidents account for 26 million nonfatal injuries each year and rank third among causes of death within the United States. Domestic accidents make up over half of these totals. Despite the centrality of physical hazards to domestic life, historians have generally left the subject of home accidents to researchers from sociology and public health. Using the term “safety work” as shorthand, this project reveals how experts and laypeople tried to control mishaps and their consequences over time. It charts the history of domestic accidents and safety work from 1900 to 1980, analyzing how and why public health education, voluntary product standards, and markets for insurance and consumer appliances came to delineate American risk management. This research describes how corporations and nonprofits established influential models for accident prevention research and policy and presents new insights into the changing realities and cultural meanings of risk and responsibility. Even as Americans have become more conscious of household risks, the burden of injury prevention continues to fall heavily on citizen-consumers. Ordinary men and women shop for “safe” products; install and repair equipment; review the latest safety advice; and perform many other tasks to keep their homes running smoothly. This project considers the historical limitations of this individualized approach to accident management and illustrates the benefits of state-centered alternatives like strict presale product regulation and subsidies for childcare and home nursing. Discussing this history with policymakers and public health practitioners has the potential to bolster existing consumer protection laws and to expand government aid programs. 

Drawing on trade catalogues, advertisements, insurance policies, magazines, case histories, product safety tests, warning labels, and other sources, this research interprets domestic accidents as part of a longer sequence of events from risk prevention to long-term recovery or disability. This project analyzes shocks, burns, falls, and choking to make four related interventions. First, its stress on safety work recenters the study of accidents on the home and the lives and labor of ordinary Americans. It represents mishaps less as results of fate or individual carelessness than as predictable byproducts of overwork and the complexity of domestic space. Second, this project clarifies how safety concerns became embedded within markets for insurance and consumer products, which left households to buy physical and mental security from for-profit corporations. Third, work itself is redefined to include learning about common hazards and shopping for “safe” appliances, factoring self-education and consumption into the labor of risk management. Finally, it shows how experts papered over differences between communities with distinct racial, economic, and geographical profiles to make middle-class white suburbia the “one-size-fits-all” model solution for home accident prevention. Overall, this project analyzes how Americans kept up with new safety practices and technologies and why they did or did not follow available social prescriptions for safe living. Accidents manifested not only as causes but also as effects of housework and compelled stakeholders to reconcile the ideal of the home-as-sanctuary with its risky and toilsome reality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
According to data from the National Safety Council, accidents account for over 200,000 deaths and 55 million serious injuries per year across the United States. Home accidents make up more than half of these totals but have attracted far less attention from researchers than transportation and workplace safety. This project has examined the overlapping histories of home injuries and consumer product safety from 1920 to 1980 and considers why experts and laypeople alike have largely failed to keep themselves and their communities safe. Since the early twentieth century, the United States has relied on what I refer to as the voluntary safety system to counteract home accidents. This system consisted of safety education, markets for safe appliances, and consumer product engineering and left the social responsibility for safety to corporations, nonprofits, and ordinary citizen-consumers. Unfortunately, this system was unable to significantly lessen home injuries, caused the costs of injuries and safety work to fall heaviest on women and low-income households, and has constrained the scope and typical methods of government intervention and public health programs up to the present.

Over the course of this grant, I have consulted collections at the New York Public Library, New York Historical Society, and Smithsonian Institution to explain the objectives, composition, and consequences of the voluntary safety system. This project has covered materials including trade catalogues, conference proceedings, advertisements, periodicals from Underwriters Laboratories and the National Safety Council, and technical standards to capture the lived realities and social meanings of home accidents. At the same time, the project consciously draws on historical case studies to propose directions for present-day safety policy. Beyond laying the foundation for my dissertation and the first book-length history of home accidents, this grant has already led to the following deliverables:

Publications

Alexander Ian Parry, Will the Supreme Court Let OSHA Enforce Biden's Vaccine Mandate? Washington Post, Jan. 7, 2022

Alexander Ian Parry, Home Is Where the Harm Is: Laundry Equipment, Injuries, and the United States Voluntary Safety System, Technology and Culture (under review); awarded the Samuel Eleazar and Rose Tartakow Levinson Prize from the Society for the History of Technology

Presentations

Historicizing Accidents: Domestic Injuries, Safety Work, and the Politics of Expertise, 1920 to 1980, Center for Injury Research and Policy, Johns Hopkins University, May 27, 2021 (invited talk)

Safety for Some: Laundry, Home Accidents, and the American Citizen Consumer, Society for the History of Technology, New Orleans, Nov. 19, 2021

Governing Safety: Consumers, Industry Self-Regulation, and the U.S. National Commission on Product Safety, 1968 to 1970, Business History Conference, Mexico City, April 8, 2022

Federalizing Safety: Consumers, Regulation, and the U.S. National Commission on Product Safety, 1968 to 1970, American Association for the History of Medicine, Saratoga Springs, April 22, 2022

Engineering Safety: Consumer Protection and the American Household, Society for the Social History of Medicine, Swansea, United Kingdom, June 29, 2022

Interdisciplinary Workshop

The digital workshop titled Governing Safety: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Injuries and the State took place over three sessions from April 11 to 18 of 2022. The workshop involved twenty participants who discussed their own research on safety and the role of the state with respect to injury prevention. I planned and convened the workshop with my advisor, Dr. Graham Mooney, and presented on the history and long-term impacts of voluntary standards. This workshop also led to the formation of the Injury Studies Research Group (ISRG), which brings together social scientists, humanists, and public health practitioners to critically analyze injuries across time and space and to translate these findings into more effective safety programs.

Overall, this project has recentered the history of accidents from disasters to smaller-scale home injuries and has described the mechanisms and shortcomings of the voluntary safety system still essential to modern injury control. These interventions, along with showing how the bodily and economic costs of home injuries mirror age, gender, race, class, disability, geography, and other social determinants of health, will enable my dissertation to speak to multiple audiences within and beyond the historical profession.
